Expectation1: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation1: Heavy product buildup is causing tight tangles that will impede scissors.
Situation2: They are approached by a member facing a difficult life choice and need to give thoughtful guidance.
Story: The bell above the salon door jingled as Mrs. Carter walked in, her hair stiff with weeks of hairspray and mousse. I greeted her warmly, ushering her to my chair, already bracing myself for the challenge ahead. The buildup in her hair was so thick, my fingers snagged in the tangles as I tried to work in the shampoo. I knew I needed to take my time, to gently detangle and condition before I could even think about cutting. But as I massaged her scalp, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from Mark, a member of my congregation. He was waiting in the church office next door, desperate for guidance about a life-altering decision. My heart squeezed. As a hairdresser, I couldn’t rush this process without risking damage to Mrs. Carter’s hair. As a pastor, I couldn’t ignore someone in spiritual crisis. Both needed me, right now, in different ways. My hands trembled slightly as I rinsed the suds away, torn between the demands of my scissors and my calling.
